(30) a. Les Français, ceux que je connais sont pour la plupart sympathiques.
The French, those that I know are for the most part nice
`As for the French, those I know are mostly nice'

tier.item: (39) Maliki-rli kaji-ngki yarlki-rni nyuntu
[dog-ERG ST-3SG.2SG bite-NPST you]
ngula-ju kapi-rna luwa-rni ngajulu-rlu.
DEM-TOP FUT-1SG.3SG shoot-NPST me-ERG
Here is why. In Lewis's sphere-based system, the truth-conditions a conditional If f, y are as follows:
If f, y is true at world i (according to the system of spheres $) if and only if either
(1) No f-world belongs to any sphere S in $i, or
(2) Some sphere S in $i does contain at least one f-world, and ffiy holds at every world in S
Take f=Èthis line is longer than 1", ye=Èthis line is longer than (1+e)" (note that e is a parameter, to be replaced by
its value, not quoted; hence the use of Quine's quasi-quotation marks).
Let $e be the sphere than contains all the worlds in which the size of the line is smaller than (1+e)" (by assumption
such a sphere exists since the similarity measure in the context of speech orders worlds by the value of e at those
worlds). Clearly there are f-world in $e if e>0. In these worlds ffiy is true. Hence the conditional should be true.
a. Reading A. `As for the dog that bites you, I'll shoot it.' (individual-centered)
b. Reading B. `If a dog bites you, then I'll shoot it.' (possibility-centered)
(39) Maliki-rli kaji-ngki yarlki-rni nyuntu
[dog-ERG ST-3SG.2SG bite-NPST you]
ngula-ju kapi-rna luwa-rni ngajulu-rlu.
DEM-TOP FUT-1SG.3SG shoot-NPST me-ERG
Here is why. In Lewis's sphere-based system, the truth-conditions a conditional If f, y are as follows:
If f, y is true at world i (according to the system of spheres $) if and only if either
(1) No f-world belongs to any sphere S in $i, or
(2) Some sphere S in $i does contain at least one f-world, and ffiy holds at every world in S
Take f=Èthis line is longer than 1", ye=Èthis line is longer than (1+e)" (note that e is a parameter, to be replaced by
its value, not quoted; hence the use of Quine's quasi-quotation marks).
Let $e be the sphere than contains all the worlds in which the size of the line is smaller than (1+e)" (by assumption
such a sphere exists since the similarity measure in the context of speech orders worlds by the value of e at those
worlds). Clearly there are f-world in $e if e>0. In these worlds ffiy is true. Hence the conditional should be true.
a. Reading A. `As for the dog that bites you, I'll shoot it.' (individual-centered)
b. Reading B. `If a dog bites you, then I'll shoot it.' (possibility-centered)
Maliki-rli kaji-ngki yarlki-rni nyuntu ngula-ju kapi-rna luwa-rni ngajulu-rlu.
[dog-ERG ST-3SG.2SG bite-NPST you] DEM-TOP FUT-1SG.3SG shoot-NPST me-ERG
Here is why. In Lewis's sphere-based system, the truth-conditions a conditional If f, y are as follows:
If f, y is true at world i (according to the system of spheres $) if and only if either
(1) No f-world belongs to any sphere S in $i, or
(2) Some sphere S in $i does contain at least one f-world, and ffiy holds at every world in S
Take f=Èthis line is longer than 1", ye=Èthis line is longer than (1+e)" (note that e is a parameter, to be replaced by
its value, not quoted; hence the use of Quine's quasi-quotation marks).
Let $e be the sphere than contains all the worlds in which the size of the line is smaller than (1+e)" (by assumption
such a sphere exists since the similarity measure in the context of speech orders worlds by the value of e at those
worlds). Clearly there are f-world in $e if e>0. In these worlds ffiy is true. Hence the conditional should be true.
a. Reading A. `As for the dog that bites you, I'll shoot it.' (individual-centered) b. Reading B. `If a dog bites you, then I'll shoot it.
(possibility-centered)
(43) Hansi, deri hat es verstanden. (German; Iatridou 1994)
Hans, he has it understood
(43) Hansi, deri hat es verstanden. (German; Iatridou 1994)
Hans, he has it understood
Hansi, deri hat es verstanden.
(German; Iatridou 1994)
Hans, he has it understood
(44) Alle haben die Vorlesung verstanden. Hans hat sie verstanden. Maria hat sie verstanden.
Und unser Freund Peter, der hat sie auch verstanden. (German)
'Everybody understood the lecture. John understood it. Mary understood it. And our
friend Bill, he understood it too.'
(44) Alle haben die Vorlesung verstanden. Hans hat sie verstanden. Maria hat sie verstanden.
Und unser Freund Peter, der hat sie auch verstanden. (German)
'Everybody understood the lecture. John understood it. Mary understood it. And our
friend Bill, he understood it too.'
Alle haben die Vorlesung verstanden. Hans hat sie verstanden. Maria hat sie verstanden. Und unser Freund Peter, der hat sie auch verstanden.
(German)
Everybody understood the lecture. John understood it. Mary understood it. And our friend Bill, he understood it too.

a. Si tu avais joué demain, tu aurais gagné.
